cnd15:1.2: To the one who points out the past,
cnd15:1.3: The undisturbed, who cuts off doubts,
cnd15:1.4: To those who have reached the other side of the dhammas,
cnd15:1.5: Those in need come with questions.

cnd15:2.1: "The one who pointed out the past": "The one who...," that is the world-honored
cnd15:2.2: person, the one who is alone, and the one without a teacher who has realized the
cnd15:2.3: truth in the Dhamma that has not been heard before, and has reached the state of
cnd15:2.4: all knowing there, the one who (reaches) the state of freedom in strength.
cnd15:2.5: "Point out," the Blessed One points out the past of himself and others, also
cnd15:2.6: points out the future, and points out the present.
cnd15:3.1: How did the Blessed One point out his past? The Blessed One pointed out his
cnd15:3.2: past: he pointed out the whole life, the second life, the third life, the fourth
cnd15:3.3: life, the fifth life, the tenth life, the twentieth life, the thirtieth life,
cnd15:3.4: the fortieth life, and also pointed out fifty births, and also pointed out a
cnd15:3.5: hundred births..., a thousand births..., one hundred thousand births..., many
cnd15:3.6: bad calamities..., many finished calamities..., also pointed out many bad
cnd15:3.7: calamities: "Who is that person? Such a name, such a surname, such a face,
cnd15:3.8: (eating) such food, such a feeling of pain and happiness, such a length of life,
cnd15:3.9: who died here and was reborn there, and what is the name, ..., who died there
cnd15:3.10: was born here." Like this, he pointed out that many previous lives had such
cnd15:4.1: How does the Blessed One point out the past of others? The Blessed One pointed
cnd15:4.2: out the past of others: he pointed out the whole life, and also pointed out the
cnd15:4.3: second life... (omitted). Like this, he pointed out that many previous lives
cnd15:5.1: When talking about the Five Hundred Prayer Suttas (Jātakas), the Blessed One
cnd15:5.2: points out the past of himself and others; when talking about the Great Causes
cnd15:5.3: Sutta [DN.14], ...; when talking about the Great Splendor Sutta [DN.17], the
cnd15:5.4: Great Steward Sutta [DN.19], the Makhādeva [MN.83], the Blessed One points out
cnd15:5.5: the past of himself and others.
cnd15:6.1: This was said by the Blessed One [DN.29]: "Cunda, Regarding the past lives,
cnd15:6.2: Tathāgata has wisdom from memory, he (can) recall as much as he hopes, Cunda,
cnd15:6.3: Regarding the future... (omitted). Cunda, Regarding the present life, the
cnd15:6.4: Tathāgata has wisdom from awakening: 'This is my last birth, and now, there is
cnd15:7.1: The wisdom of the root is the power of the Tathāgata; the underlying tendency of
cnd15:7.2: all living beings and the underlying tendency of the troubles is the power of
cnd15:7.3: the Tathāgata; the wisdom of the two gods...; the wisdom of great compassion...;
cnd15:7.4: the wisdom of all knowers...; barrier-free wisdom...; there is no attachment, no
cnd15:7.5: repulsion, and barrier-free wisdom is the Tathāgata power. In this way, the
cnd15:7.6: Blessed One points out the past, future, and present of himself and others, he
cnd15:8.1: "[Like this Venerable Posāla]": "Like this," the continuation of the sentences,
cnd15:8.2: the connection of the words, the completion of the sentences, the combination of
cnd15:8.3: words, this is the order of the sentence, which is "like this." "Venerable,"
cnd15:8.4: this is a synonym of love, respect, and obedience. "Posāla," the name, title,
cnd15:8.5: security of the Brāhmaṇa, title, word, phrase.
cnd15:9.1: "The one who is not disturbed, the one who cuts off doubts": "Disturbance is
cnd15:9.2: called thirst, that is greed, lust, acquiescence, conformity, joy, desire,
cnd15:9.3: obsession, taking, contaminated, disturbance, fraud, (reincarnation) root cause,
cnd15:9.4: (bitter) fertility, tailoring (greed), net, river, bondage, rope, attachment,
cnd15:9.5: accumulation, companionship, desire, intimate interaction, forest, jungle, love,
cnd15:9.6: expectation, relationship, desire for form, desire for sounds, desire for
cnd15:9.7: smells, desire for tastes, desire for touches, desire for acquisition, desire
cnd15:9.8: for wealth, desire for sons, desire for life, the state of desire, hope, prayer,
cnd15:9.9: greedy appearance, possessing greed, inquiring for profit, illegal greed,
cnd15:9.10: improper greed, hope, envy, desire for desire, desire for nothingness, desire
cnd15:9.11: for form, formless thirst, extinguished thirst, form thirst, sound thirst, smell
cnd15:9.12: thirst, taste thirst, touch thirst, dhamma thirst, torrent, harness, binding,
cnd15:9.13: clinging, obstacles, covering, defilements, potential trends of troubles,
cnd15:9.14: entanglement, vines, stinginess, suffering roots, causes of suffering,
cnd15:9.15: occurrence of suffering, magical nets, magical hooks, magical food, the realm of
cnd15:9.16: the devil, the residence of the devil, the state of the devil, the bondage of
cnd15:9.17: the devil, the river of thirst, the net of thirst, the rope of thirst, the sea
cnd15:9.18: of thirst, craving, greed, and the root of unwholesomeness. That disturbance,
cnd15:9.19: thirst, for Buddha, the Blessed One, has been cut off, the root.... Therefore,
cnd15:9.20: the Buddha is the undisturbed. In the state of that disturbance being
cnd15:9.21: disconnection, the Blessed One does not waver; does not shake when he does not
cnd15:9.22: get it (obtain something); does not shake when he has reputation; does not shake
cnd15:9.23: when he has no reputation; does not shake with praise; does not shake with
cnd15:9.24: reprimand; does not shake at times; does not shake, does not move, does not
cnd15:9.25: tremble. "The doubter," Doubts are called doubts: doubt of suffering, doubt of
cnd15:9.26: the path leading to suffering, doubt of the future, doubt of the past, doubt of
cnd15:9.27: the future and the past, doubt of causal connections, such doubts, suspicions,
cnd15:9.28: doubtful states, confusion, hesitation, crossroads, inconsistent grasping,
cnd15:9.29: hesitating, incomplete understanding, stiff state, confusion of mind. That doubt
cnd15:9.30: has been cut off, severed, and destroyed for the Buddha and the Blessed One, has
cnd15:9.31: been cut off, ..., burned by the fire of wisdom. Therefore, the Buddha is the
cnd15:10.1: "Reached the other side in all dhammas": The Blessed One is the one who has
cnd15:10.2: reached the other shore of the dhammas; knowing ...; abandoning ...;
cnd15:10.3: practice...; testifying...; those on the other side: those who have reached the
cnd15:10.4: other side of all dhammas; those who have reached the other side of all
cnd15:10.5: suffering knowledge; ...of all polluted renunciations; ...of the practice of the
cnd15:10.6: four holy paths; ...of the testimony of destruction; the one who waits until he
cnd15:10.7: has reached the other shore, he is the free reacher (one who arrives) in the
cnd15:10.8: holy precepts, the highest (pāramitā) reacher; the free reacher and the highest
cnd15:10.9: reacher in the holy sanctuary; the free reacher in the holy wisdom, the highest,
cnd15:10.10: the one who has reached the end; the one who is free and the highest in the
cnd15:10.11: sacred liberation, the one who has reached the other side, the one who has
cnd15:10.12: reached the ultimate (target); the one who has reached finality, the one who has
cnd15:10.13: reached the end; has reached the border; ...reached rescue; reached shelter;
cnd15:10.14: reached the refuge; the one without terror; the one who has reached no fear, the
cnd15:10.15: one without death; the one who has reached undeath; the one who has reached
cnd15:10.16: Nibbāna; he is a person who has descended into a state, a person who has
cnd15:11.1: "The needy come with a question": I come with questions as needed, I come if I
cnd15:11.2: want to ask questions, I come if I want to hear questions, the needy come with
cnd15:11.3: questions. Or, the inquirers of the question have the need, the one who wants to
cnd15:11.4: ask the question, the one who wants to hear, the needy (will) come, approach,
cnd15:11.5: visit. Or, when you have a question, you can and you have enough reason to tell
cnd15:11.6: and answer the question I asked, "Please bear this burden."
cnd15:12.1: <em>82 : The person for whom form has disappeared,
cnd15:12.2: The person who has abandoned the body,
cnd15:12.3: The seer of "nothing" inside and outside of oneself,
cnd15:12.4: Sakyamuni! I ask about this wisdom,
cnd15:12.5: How should people like that be guided?
cnd15:12.6: <em>82 : The person for whom form has disappeared,
cnd15:12.7: The person who has abandoned the body,
cnd15:12.8: The seer of "nothing" inside and outside of oneself,
cnd15:12.9: Sakyamuni! I ask about this wisdom,
cnd15:12.10: How should people like that be guided?
cnd15:12.11: <em>82 : The person for whom form has disappeared,
cnd15:12.12: The person who has abandoned the body,
cnd15:12.13: The seer of "nothing" inside and outside of oneself,
cnd15:12.14: Sakyamuni! I ask about this wisdom,
cnd15:12.15: How should people like that be guided?
cnd15:12.16: <em>82 : The person for whom form has disappeared,
cnd15:12.17: The person who has abandoned the body,
cnd15:12.18: The seer of "nothing" inside and outside of oneself,
cnd15:12.19: Sakyamuni! I ask about this wisdom,
cnd15:12.20: How should people like that be guided?
cnd15:12.21: <em>82 : The person for whom form has disappeared,
cnd15:12.22: The person who has abandoned the body,
cnd15:12.23: The seer of "nothing" inside and outside of oneself,
cnd15:12.24: Sakyamuni! I ask about this wisdom,
cnd15:12.25: How should people like that be guided?
cnd15:13.1: "Those whose form has disappeared": What is form? The state of thought,
cnd15:13.2: cognition, and cognition of the entrants or the deceased, or those who live in
cnd15:13.3: the realm of life, is the state of consciousness. "Those who have disappeared":
cnd15:13.4: The four formless attainments are those who have disappeared, those who have
cnd15:13.5: left, those who have passed through, those who have transcended, and those who
cnd15:14.1: "The person who has abandoned all bodies": All his rebirth bodies have been
cnd15:14.2: given up, those who have crossed that portion, and his body has been suppressed
cnd15:14.3: and given up by those who have given up.
cnd15:15.1: "Inside and outside of oneself, the seer of 'nothing'": "Nothing" means dwelling
cnd15:15.2: in nothingness. For what reason is "nothing" dwelling in nothingness? Everyone
cnd15:15.3: who enters (mindfully) and dwells until the boundlessness of consciousness, and
cnd15:15.4: then after coming out of there, (observes that) that consciousness does not
cnd15:15.5: exist, disappears, and is wiped out. He sees "nothing," and for this reason
cnd15:16.1: "Sakyamuni! I will ask the wisdom": "Sakyamuni," .... "I ask wisdom," I ask your
cnd15:16.2: wisdom, I ask your knowledge, I ask your all-seeing wisdom, I ask the wisdom of
cnd15:16.3: the all-knowing one: What is it like, what is established, what method, and what
cnd15:16.4: type of wisdom should be desired?"
cnd15:17.1: "How should a person like that be guided": How should he be guided, be tempered,
cnd15:17.2: be comforted, be told, be considered, be seen, and be made clear? How? How
cnd15:17.3: should that higher wisdom be made to arise? "That type of person," that type of
cnd15:17.4: person, that fixator, that similar person, who has attained the sphere of
cnd15:18.4: Knowing that the survivor is the winner,
cnd15:18.5: (Or) the one who who is stuck.
cnd15:18.9: Knowing that the survivor is the winner,
cnd15:18.10: (Or) the one who who is stuck.
cnd15:18.14: Knowing that the survivor is the winner,
cnd15:18.15: (Or) the one who who is stuck.
cnd15:18.19: Knowing that the survivor is the winner,
cnd15:18.20: (Or) the one who who is stuck.
cnd15:18.24: Knowing that the survivor is the winner,
cnd15:18.25: (Or) the one who who is stuck.
cnd15:19.1: "Knowing all states of consciousness": The Blessed One knows the four
cnd15:19.2: consciousnesses because of his creation, and he knows the seven consciousnesses
cnd15:19.3: because of the incarnation. How is it that the Blessed One knows the four
cnd15:19.4: consciousnesses because of his creation? This is said by the Blessed One:
cnd15:19.5: "Bhikkhus! When consciousness abides with form, it stays in form, stands on
cnd15:19.6: form, is supported by form, and with a sprinkle of joy in it, it will grow and
cnd15:19.7: expand. Bhikkhus! When consciousness abides with feeling..., ...perceiving...."
cnd15:20.1: How is the Blessed One the one who knows the seven consciousness due to the
cnd15:20.2: incarnation? This was said by the Blessed One:
cnd15:21.1: "Bhikkhus! Beings with all types of bodies and all types of thoughts, such as:
cnd15:21.2: people, certain heavens, and certain people who have descended into the realm,
cnd15:22.1: Bhikkhus! There are all types of beings with a single mind, such as the Brahma
cnd15:22.2: who reborn as the first, this is the second consciousness.
cnd15:23.1: Bhikkhus! Beings with a single body and all types of thoughts, such as the
cnd15:23.2: heaven of light and sound, this is the third consciousness.
cnd15:24.1: Bhikkhus! Beings who have a single body and a single mind, such as: the sky of
cnd15:24.2: pure heaven, this is the fourth consciousness.
cnd15:25.1: Bhikkhus! There is the transcendence of thinking with all forms, the extinction
cnd15:25.2: of thinking with the opposite (opposing factors), and all types of thinking
cnd15:25.3: without thinking, (knowing): 'The void is boundless,' to beings in the boundless
cnd15:25.4: emptiness, this is the fifth consciousness.
cnd15:26.1: Bhikkhus! After surpassing all boundless emptiness (knowing): 'Knowledge
cnd15:26.2: (consciousness) is boundless,' the sentient beings who reach the boundlessness
cnd15:26.3: of consciousness, this is the sixth consciousness.
cnd15:27.1: Bhikkhus! After having transcended all boundlessness of consciousness (knowing):
cnd15:27.2: 'There is nothing,' the sentient beings who reach nothingness are (in) the
cnd15:27.3: seventh consciousness. In this way, the Blessed One knows the seven
cnd15:29.1: "The Tathāgata is the knower who proves": "The knower who proves," the Tathāgata
cnd15:29.2: is the one who proves the knowing, the sure knower, the penetrator. This is said
cnd15:29.3: by the Blessed One [DN.29]: "Cunda, If a question about the past is untrue,
cnd15:29.4: unrealistic, unprofitable, Tathāgata does not answer it. Cunda, If the question
cnd15:29.5: about the past is true, truthful, but unprofitable, the Tathāgata does not
cnd15:29.6: answer it. Cunda, if the question about the past is true, truthful, and
cnd15:29.7: profitable, the Tathāgata knows the right time to answer. Cunda, if a question
cnd15:29.8: about the future the future.... Cunda, if a question about the present....
cnd15:29.9: Cunda, like this, in the past, the future, and the present Dhamma, the Tathāgata
cnd15:29.10: is the speaker in the right time, the speaker of the fact, the speaker of the
cnd15:29.11: benefit, such as the speaker of the Dhamma, therefore it is called 'Tathāgata.'
cnd15:30.1: Cunda, including the world with of heavens, demons, and Brahma; in the
cnd15:30.2: generations with the Samaṇas, Brāhmaṇas, heavens, and humans, whatever he sees,
cnd15:30.3: hears, feels, knows, gains, asks, and is followed by intentions, that Everything
cnd15:30.4: has been enlightened by the Tathāgata, so it is called 'Tathāgata;' Cunda,
cnd15:30.5: whenever he speaks, talks, and demonstrates in the night of enlightenment, he
cnd15:30.6: says, talks, and shows that everything is the same as it really is, so it is
cnd15:30.7: called 'Tathāgata;' Cunda, the Tathāgata is the one who does what he says; the
cnd15:30.8: one who speaks as he does, and the one who does it like this; the one who speaks
cnd15:30.9: as he does it is called 'Tathāgata;' Cunda, including the world with the
cnd15:30.10: heavens, demons, and Brahma; among the generations including the Samaṇas,
cnd15:30.11: Brāhmaṇas, heavens, and people, the Tathāgata is the conqueror, the unconquered,
cnd15:30.12: the all-seeing, and the free, and so is called the 'Tathāgata.'"
cnd15:31.1: "Know the survivor": The Blessed One knows that the survivor is here because of
cnd15:31.2: the deeds of kamma: "This person has passed away to the world of suffering, evil
cnd15:31.3: interest, lower realm, and hell after death through the disintegration of the
cnd15:31.4: body." And the one who knows that exists here: "This person has passed away to
cnd15:31.5: the animal world after death by the disintegration of the body." The Blessed One
cnd15:31.6: knows that this is here due to the deeds of kamma: "This person has passed away
cnd15:31.7: after the disintegration of the body, to the world of hungry ghosts." The
cnd15:31.8: Blessed One knows that he is here because of his kamma: "This person has passed
cnd15:31.9: away after death through the disintegration of his body." The Blessed One knows
cnd15:31.10: that he is here because of his kamma: "With the disintegration of the body,
cnd15:31.11: human beings have been reborn to the realm of goodness and heaven after death."
cnd15:32.1: This was said by the Blessed One [MN.12]:
cnd15:33.1: "Again, Sāriputta! Here, after knowing the heart so well, I know someone: 'This
cnd15:33.2: individual who walks the way and behaves like that has entered the
cnd15:33.3: disintegration of the body, and will be reborn into the way of suffering, evil,
cnd15:33.4: lower realms, and hell after death.'
cnd15:34.1: Again, Sāriputta! ...in the animal world after death.
cnd15:34.2: Again, Sāriputta! ...in the world of hungry ghosts after death.
cnd15:34.3: Again, Sāriputta! ...in the human realm after death.
cnd15:34.4: Again, Sāriputta! ...in the way of goodness and heaven after death.
cnd15:35.1: Again, Sāriputta! Here, after knowing the heart so well, I know someone: 'This
cnd15:35.2: individual who walks the way and behaves like that has entered the extinction of
cnd15:35.3: all the troubles, and will enter in the life after witnessing the wisdom to
cnd15:35.4: testify, then live in the mind free from worry, with the relief of wisdom.'"
cnd15:36.1: "The victor, (or) the one who is stuck": The "victor" who has nowhere. "The
cnd15:36.2: victor," the one who overcomes the solution by liberation, the one who overcomes
cnd15:36.3: the solution there, the one like that. Or, the Blessed One knows that: this
cnd15:36.4: person is the one who overcomes the solution by form, the solution by sound, the
cnd15:36.5: solution by smell, the solution by taste, the solution by touch, the solution by
cnd15:36.6: family, the solution by the group, the winner of a residence, the winner of
cnd15:36.7: profit, the winner of reputation, the winner of praise, the winner of joy, the
cnd15:36.8: winner of clothing, the winner of group food (eating meals with the group), the
cnd15:36.9: winner of shelter, of the needs of patients and medical necessities, the
cnd15:36.10: interpreter, the victorious interpreter, the ruler-victorious, the
cnd15:36.11: Abhidhamma-victorious, Arahant-victorious: the one who always begs for food, the
cnd15:36.12: dung-sweeping victorious, the three-clothing victorious, those who beg for food
cnd15:36.13: and overcome solutions, those who do not suffer from food after eating, those
cnd15:36.14: who often sit and do not sleep, those who live anywhere, those who overcome
cnd15:36.15: solutions, those who (through) first jhāna overcome solutions, those who
cnd15:36.16: (through) second jhāna ..., and those who (through) third jhāna..., those who
cnd15:36.17: are in the fourth jhāna are the winners of the solution, those who dwell for the
cnd15:36.18: solution in the boundless void (fifth/first immaterial), ...in the boundlessness
cnd15:36.19: of consciousness, ...in nothingness, and those who do not dwell (in nothingness;
cnd15:36.20: neither perception nor non-perception; eighth), for the solution.
cnd15:37.1: "The one who is stuck" means the one who has no place, the one who is stuck, the
cnd15:37.2: one who is stuck in kamma, the one who is repaid, the one who is serious, and
cnd15:37.3: the one who regenerates. Or, the Blessed One knows: This person is a person who
cnd15:38.1: <em>84 : After knowing the arising of nothingness,
cnd15:38.2: Like this, is the knot of joy,
cnd15:38.3: After he knows in this way,
cnd15:38.4: He sees clearly with insight there;
cnd15:38.7: <em>84 : After knowing the arising of nothingness,
cnd15:38.8: Like this, is the knot of joy,

cnd15:38.10: He sees clearly with insight there;

cnd15:38.14: Like this, is the knot of joy,
cnd15:38.15: After he knows in this way,

cnd15:38.20: Like this, is the knot of joy,
cnd15:38.21: After he knows in this way,
cnd15:38.22: He sees clearly with insight there;

cnd15:38.26: Like this, is the knot of joy,
cnd15:38.27: After he knows in this way,
cnd15:38.28: He sees clearly with insight there;
cnd15:38.31: <em>84 : After knowing the arising of nothingness,
cnd15:38.32: Like this, is the knot of joy,
cnd15:38.33: After he knows in this way,
cnd15:38.34: He sees clearly with insight there;
cnd15:39.1: "After knowing the arising of nothingness: "Arising of nothingness" is called a
cnd15:39.2: creation that leads to nothingness. Knowing that the creation that leads to
cnd15:39.3: nothingness is "nothing arises," after knowing it is "adhesion," after knowing
cnd15:39.4: it is "binding," after knowing it is an "obstacle," after understanding, after
cnd15:39.5: measuring, after judging, after separating, after clarifying.
cnd15:40.1: "Like this, the joyful knot": The happy knot is called formless greed. The kamma
cnd15:40.2: is attached, fixed, and obstructed by formless greed. After knowing that
cnd15:40.3: formless greed is the "happy knot," after knowing it is "adhesion," .... Like
cnd15:41.1: "After proving this in this way": After proving this in this way, after
cnd15:41.2: understanding, after weighing, after judging, after separating, after
cnd15:42.1: "Afterwards, seeing with insight there": "There," enter into the place of no
cnd15:42.2: possessions, and then after exiting from there, with insight of the impermanence
cnd15:42.3: in the mind and mental states that arise; as insight of the suffering; of the
cnd15:42.4: sickness... (omitted). With insight he leaves, he sees, watches, contemplates,
cnd15:43.1: "This is his true wisdom": This is his true, factual, correct, and non-reversed
cnd15:44.1: "Completed Brāhmaṇa": "Brāhmaṇa," the exclusion of the seven dhammas is the
cnd15:44.2: Brāhmaṇa: seeing is excluded, doubt is excluded, abstinence is excluded, greed
cnd15:44.3: is excluded, aversion is excluded, illusion is eliminated, sloth is eliminated,
cnd15:44.4: those evil and unwholesome methods are eliminated: those that are contaminated,
cnd15:44.5: those that are no longer there, those that are fearful, those who will suffer
cnd15:44.6: the consequences, and those who will die in the future.
cnd15:45.7: Like this can be called Brāhmaṇa."
cnd15:46.1: "Completed Brāhmaṇa": Seven common people, including seven types of learned,
cnd15:46.2: live, live together, dwell, and stay, those who have what is deserved, those who
cnd15:46.3: reach what should be reached, those who testify to what should be testified, the
cnd15:46.4: Arahant has completed what should be done, the burden has been discharged, his
cnd15:46.5: own interests have been achieved, the knots of being have been wiped out, and he
cnd15:46.6: is liberated with ultimate wisdom. He is a person who has descended into a
cnd15:46.7: state, has practiced... (omitted), ...life and death, without his rebirth.
cnd15:47.1: At the end of these verses... "The Blessed One is my teacher, I am a disciple."
